column1: 2275830: I consent to have my responses used for future academic studies.
column2: 2275846: What GenAI tools did you use (for example ChatGPT, Claude, Dall-E, Gemini etc)? Please list all the tools your used in preparation of your report.
column3: 2275847: I feel confident/capable when using GenAI
column4: 2275835: GenAI was useful for preparing my report.
column5:
2275831: In CHEN90022 Design Project, you are free to use GenAI however you choose.
What percentage of the words in your final report do you think were generated by AI (cut-pasted across)?
column6: 2275844: How did you use GenAI in the preparation of your report? List all use-cases as a series of dot-points with short explanations of how you used it.
column7: 2275845: How was GenAI most useful to you? What single use-case was most helpful in preparation of your report?
column8: 2275849: How reliable did you find the GenAI outputs?

column6:
Mainly for finding starting points for further research the old fashion way, casting a wide net with a genAI search, and then digging deeper into any ideas that matched with what I was searching for.

In terms of actual report content generation, I only used GenAI in my section on environmental impact of the project. I had a list of about 8-10 dot points containing key points, information, and statistics I had gathered and I used genAI to quickly create a readable paragraph from these dot points. From there a decent amount of editing was undertaken, but it made a positive impact mentally as I didn't have to construct the large paragraph from scratch I was now just polishing and editing an existing paragraph which is a much less mentally intimidating task.

This helped aleviate the feeling of being overwhelmed by the sheer volume of writng that can come with these large reports, thus reducing procrastination and enhancing my personal workflow.
column7: While the text generation from dot points was great, being able to quickly gain a summary of a given area of the project just from one or two prompts was the most valuable to me.
column8: Great for rewriting my own dot points into paragraphs, not so great for getting specific data on things. For example when asking about existing desalination facilities in the Pilbara, it invented one that sounded reasonable but didn't actually exists.

column6:
- I started by asking how I should research. When I am just starting research, the first difficulty I encounter is what and how I should research. Asking this question to the AI, drawing a path for myself and researching accordingly prevents me from wasting a great deal of my time. In this respect, I find AI very useful. And used AI from this view of point so much for this assignment.

- I used AI by asking some specific information directly in the form of whether it is true or not.

- When I do any kind of  research (for example on Google), I open at least ten pages and often only read two. But since I search for the answer to my question directly with the help of AI, I can often read what it writes, do more detailed research on the research and read in more detail. Chatgbt was not very useful in this regard, but artificial intelligences with access to the internet are very useful in this regard.

- Previously, I used extra tools such as Grammerly for report writing, especially for grammar. Now I can only correct grammar with artificial intelligence. I used this a lot in report writing.

- I find it very useful in creating tables and algorithms on any subject. I asked a few times how to create the tables I use in the report with the help of chatgbt.

- I also use ChatGBT's coding skills a lot in my daily life. I haven't used it before for macro excel. It was useful for me to create macro excel code.
column7: The research part ( I really don't like spending time for long and unuseful research, I prefer being productive.) and the grammar correction part was probably the most useful part.
column8: It depends on the topic, but mostly the output from GenAI is not reliable. I think it is also related to the questions or commands that you gave it.

column6:
Research Ideation

-It helped in the ideation of my research. I inputted the questions from the brief, and it give me prompts on what I need to research in.

Writing of the report

-In inputted the data I collected, as well as the preliminary writing I did previously in a draft document into chatgpt and ask it to collate my research and create a sample report for me. However, this was insufficient so I kept prompting it to change a few words or include something extra. I f it was lacking I went online to search more articles so that I can get appropriate research material to be inputted into my report.
column7: I think the research ideation was the most useful for me. This helped clarify me the objectives of the report. It allowed me to focus on specific tasks. I was also able to ask chatgpt to perform a first principles analysis for my section and it provided me questions I could think about for market research.
column8: They are somewhat reliable but it is necessary to check if it is not just repeating what you said and if you want to create a perfect report, you do need a self-written report beforehand. It is an amazing tool but it should be treated as a tool. However, I think there was an overreliance on it from my side for assignment A1. Going to improve on it a bit more for the other assignments. Sorry for the rambling.

column6:
Chat GPT: 

* Made a group logo for our minutes form (kind of Dall-E, not sure how this would be classified)

* Made chatbot to answer questions about green DRI (minimally used)

* Dumped dotpointed ideas into Chat GTP and asked it to craft me report-style paragraphs 

* Got it to summarise the Exec Summary and then edited / re-wrote it 

* Asked for summaries of key constraints based on its training dataset 

* Got it to write Exel Macro using plain English and then pieced together differnet cod sections / got it to explain what different parts did

* Some proofreading for typos and syntax in other ppl's sections
column7: Taking dot points to paragraphs. Writing Excel VBA code. Both of these use-cases saved me so much time.
column8:
Eh, quite? I wouldn't trust it, but it seemed to be correct ~90% of the time in my use of it for this assignment, but that's not high enough to "trust" it to write things without proof-reading and supervision (if you would call it that). 

 

Note to the reader: re the 50% figure above, I actually have no idea. I suspect my written sections were about 50% GTP-written, but it's hard to say how that compares with the overall report, and also if that number should be higher or lower given the iterative approach taken towards writing.

column6:
* Primarily used GenAI for early learning of content related to green steel production and various technologies. 

* When writing the report I asked it occasionally for rephrasing of complex sentences, whereby I usually identified that what I had initially fed it was not clear enough in meaning, so this would help me reconceptualise the sentence.

* I sometimes asked it to suggest financial jargon to me for concepts that I was trying to explain, e.g. eco-labelling premium, premium tolerance/demand elasticity. 

* I can't recall ever copying whole sentences, they were often too verbose, and the effort required to get ChatGPT to refine it was not worth it.
column7:
Most useful for quick learning about a topic, the common technologies, and like process descriptions.

Other single use case was finding the right financial jargon in market analysis.
column8: Pretty reliable for concepts, but would get confused when you dive into detail on different processes and their respective advantages/disadvantages.

column7: Using chatgpt to cite references and write large paragraphs for the introduction, conclusion, and executive summary was likely the most time saving uses, but I believe using it for quick research to get a number or short answer for something is the most helpful throughout the entire process of researching and writing.
column8: Very

column6:
* Information gathering: used to understand simple to moderate concepts. Not used for specific statistics or complex topics unless backed up by RAG input.

* Paper summaries: used to summarise the key points in a research paper, including any key statistics. Could tune the summary to the questions I needed answered.

* Project guidance: used to suggest areas to research relevant to the assignment brief, and specific questions that might be useful to answer.

* Report skeleton writing: Providing an initial paragraph for new sections of writing which I can edit and write around. Gives a launching point for each writing section that I typically find difficult to do.

* Report structure: suggesting what to include in certain sections of the report, and what order to include them. (Although it typically provided too large of a suggestion before iterating it shorter with more requests).

* Rewriting of sections: inputting sections of text that I had written and asking for specific improvements, such as flow, brevity, clarity, readability, or simply removing grammar errors. 

* Excel coding: asking it to code something I have explained with words, specifically for the macros in Excel. Adjusting the code based on errors or changes needed is simple, to do so myself or iterate the code in GPT. 

* Referencing: input several downloaded pdfs and asking for references. Also used to sort and remove duplicates of final reference list.

* Provide a summary of use cases for this quiz.

* Perform mass balances on simple chemical equations: The maths was checked by hand but was typically correct. 

* Generate a relevant image for the cover page of the report.
column7: Using GPT to write code for the excel macros. Allows for relatively complex coding to be completed through several sentence descriptions, without any knowledge of the coding language. This is also very easy to troubleshoot if errors arise, and allows for some learning of the code since it is typically annotated clearly. Although this was only a small section of the project, it likely saved the most time for a singular section.
column8: Moderate to highly reliable. Struggles with very specific chemical engineering concepts, and makes claims or assumptions that are difficult to prove/disprove (false-positive). Reliable for simple to moderate difficulty information summaries, and most mathematical queries.

column6:
Assisted with using gen AI to code excel macros

Very limited usage to create summaries of new topics

Created a RAG to assist with social and environmental section which got little use as my focus was not on this area
column7: VBA code generation
column8: Very unreliable. The biggest issue I found was the memory function seemed to cause some consistent errors in terminology. I did some research of fluid bed reactors, and then basically any subsequent reduction process would be referred to as a fluid bed irrespective of actual technology.

column6:
* a more advance version of Wikipedia to obtain preliminary knowledge regarding green ironmaking process and its challenges of full commercialization; I entered a prompt, asking ChatGPT to briefly explain to me green hydrogen ironmaking process, its potential to contribute to a more sustainable and greener future, and what hurdles prevent its full-scale industrialization

* a time-saving tool to obtain brief overviews on the most critical findings from research/review articles in green hydrogen ironmaking; I collected several research/review articles on the topic of green ironmaking, created GPTs, uploaded the articles, requested retrieval augmented generation from the attached files, and asked GPTs to provide a brief overview of each article and their most important findings.

* an effective tool for getting very specific questions (partially) answered/(almost) unique ideas assessed in a considerably reliable way; After the preliminary research stage, I came up with several very specific questions and wanted to get them answered in a reliable way. Knowing that outputs from the standard use of ChatGPT would not be reliable, I took my time to collect some relevant articles and requested retrieval augmented generation from a separate GPT as per the information in the articles I found. I then asked my specific (mostly technical) questions and got them attempted in a reliable way, which I believe helped me a lot to realize the potential of this tool for my future learning.
column7:
The most useful aspect of GenAI for me was its ability to quickly provide a brief overview of a number of research articles which I found useful for the feasibility study. 

A single use-case most helpful for me was the time when I had a very specific question in mind regarding the technology part of green ironmaking process, and I researched and collected 15 articles in an attempt to just find an answer to that question. I then uploaded all of the articles into a separate GPT I created for myself and requested retrieval augmented generation from the attached files. Afterwards, I introduced my very specific question and asked GenAI to check if any of the articles had a (partly) suitable answer for my question.

I do love researching, however there are times when there are just too many things to do, and you just cannot manage reading all the articles by yourself. So, this possibility has added tremendous value to my learning, and now I enjoy researching and coming up with very interesting scenarios more than ever because I know that I can utilize GenAI for this specific purpose and get my questions answered and (almost) unique ideas assessed in no time.
column8: The reliability of GenAI outputs from ChatGPT is certainly questionable as, if put shortly and simply, the system is designed to satisfy users' needs. Therefore, depending on the specificity of the prompt attempted/question asked, the reliability of the output changes to a significant extent. To account for this possibility, instead of directly asking very specific questions and requesting reliable answers, most of the time, I would spend some time in researching and collecting some relevant research articles, create separate GPTs, upload the articles, request retrieval augmented generation, and ask GPTs to look for potential answers to my question based on the information provided in the attached files. This way, I would ensure comparatively much higher reliability of outputs by providing GPTS with a certain scope thus not allowing them to expand it however they want.

* I used the key findings doc to start creating the Executive Summary, then another member used it to create one paragraph about each section of the report. Using these two sections I manually combined them both to create the executive summary.

column7:
For me, the "monkey work" as you put it, is often the most tedious part of completing these assessments, so using it was helpful in sections where I had already done the "thinking work" and just needed to do the "rewriting or summarising work". 

This leads to the point that I found most useful was the Executive Summary example that I gave in the previous section.  

* I used the key findings doc to start creating the Executive Summary, then another member used it to create one paragraph about each section of the report. Using these two sections I manually combined them both to create the executive summary.
column8:
Completing an assessment using chat gpt was an interesting experience. To me it highlighted how these models produce the "average next answer" which often results in work that is quite average. I often found that I needed to take out a lot of the adverbs within the writing as they made is sound like it was written by an AI. 

As always it works better in a subtractive manner (get it to simplify or rewrite), rather than to create and expand as it just ends up making up BS or just filling out paragraphs with fluff.

column7: The RAG tool was something I hadn't used before. I found it extremely beneficial as it would only extract information from the specific files I uploaded. This gave me confidence in the information it was providing me with (even though I still searched through the document to double check). This tool saved a lot of time in this respect as many documents/reports contained extensive text.
column8: As previously mentioned - highly reliable. Normal use of chatgpt in the past never filled me with confidence in its answers given its LLM basis. The RAG tool significantly increased my confidence in information provided.

column2:
The group initially built a GPT for background and broad research on the steel industry and green steel. This was done by using explore GPTs then my GPTs and uploading most material from the introductory resources in the LMS, with some other papers as well. 

Also, towards the end of the study, I built a GPT to be an expert in LCAs. Uploading multiple files of LCAs both theory and their application to different scenarios.

column7:
It helps me with my professional writing a lot. 

Since English is not my first language, I'm not good at writing things, and sometimes I write repeated things. I use GenAI to fix my writing errors or look for better words to express what I want to write; for example, when I write a paragraph, I'll put it in the AI to let it restructure it for me to be more professional. If I think the paragraph is good, I will paste it, or fix my paragraph with some words it has.

column2: ChatGTP 4.0 was the tool that I used for Assignment 1.
column6:
Here are the listing of things that I used ChatGTP for.

1. After brainstorming ideas for different sections of the report, use ChatGTP to regenerate ideas and compare with mine. 

2. Generating whole paragraphs from dot points and ideas

3. Ask ChatGTP to search for reliable sources, saving me time scooping information from the website. 

4. Using ChatGTP to shorten my paragraph without changing the concepts and facts in the original paragraph.
column7:
My typical steps for using GenAI will be 

1. Brainstorming ideas for the section.

2. Use AI tools to generate ideas to cross compare with my ideas, take note of the differences and similarities

3. First research the similar ideas that both ChatGTP and I thought about by using google scholar and other reliable websites, then further confirm the differences by using both ChatGTP and the internet, and only carry on researching about the true and useful ideas for the report.

4. Writing down dot points for different sections of the report, completing the draft that contains only dot points and short paragraphs.

5. Put the dot points into ChatGTP and using it to generate a longer paragraphs with more professional languages. 

6. Check the integrity and central concepts of the paragraphs generated by ChatGTP, making sure they are expressing my opinion and including all my researches. After all boxes are ticked, copy and past the passage into that section of the report.

7. Put in citations into the paragraph to support the facts.

8. Cross check with different members in the team.
column8:
I fount it very reliable in terms of generating paragraphs and improving my choices of words. When I asked it to generate ideas, it was reliable for most of the time, I always double check any information that I decided to use that is generated by AI, it was never wrong, but often was unclear or misunderstood the source. For example, I asked it to compare between an alkaline electrolyzer and a PEM cell, it recommended using alkaline because it has high efficiency and low cost over the other. It is true, but according to my research, ChatGTP failed to capture the fact that the current density of a PEM cell is about 10 times of an alkaline cell. 

In short, the information that ChatGTP picks up from the online sources could be wrong for not taking all the details into consideration and only yielding results based on overview.

column6:
For the sections where I contributed, I used GenAI to help revise some of my paragraphs after writing. Mainly using the prompt 'Please check this paragraph for clarity, but keep the ideas'. I then compared the two paragraphs and edited some of my paragraphs to gather conciseness and remove repeated contents.
Background research using a custom RAG tool. I used BingAI to get an understanding of the project and contents, then obtained the sources it provides in each response. The articles that it provided were generally open source, or publicly available, so those were used in my RAG. Then I would review the abstract if it matched the information I needed and inputted it into the RAG. The RAG helped with basic ideation and gave points to think about for the project.
VBA coding. I used ChatGPT to help code, making a RAG with chemical engineering economics background. I gave up on this RAG as the response time was super slow after too much code was implemented. The general ChatGPT was more efficient and I could feed information via screenshot to simplify my instructions. I prompted ChatGPT to make code and not give code until instructions were fully listed. I also checked that it was doing what I wanted to first before getting code. This means asking for a detailed explanation of what I have asked so far and listing it out.
column7: Most useful in background research and coding. Coding was super easy and reliable since it can directly be seen on Excel, not sure how it would work and be able to verify it with other languages.
column8: Mostly reliable in my case. There were errors in adjusting ChatGPT's code at first, but once I got more clear messages and had a better system to explain it, then it was clear.

column6:
-              Taking out values from sources and asking for what pages etc a specific part what

-              Developing the macro

-              Basic writing fixes (proof reading)

-              Some idea generation and validation

-              Asking for references
column7: In the initial research stages it helped sort through all the information I found
column8: About 50/50, had to check what it said but when it was right it was helpful. It sometimes just went in circles which was a waste of time

column6:
* After writing most paragraphs I would put them into chatGPT and ask it to make them more coherent and professional

* I used it to generate an initial summary outline for the feasibility report, with subheadings of things to include

* I used it to generate a list of things to consider under my assigned sections (i.e. a general outline of the section structure) to help start my research process
column7: The most useful aspect was helping clean up paragraphs so that they flowed more coherently.
column8: Not very reliable, however, didn't rely on it very much for research facts in general

column6:
1. Use to rewrite my writing since my writing is not academic/professional enough. ChatGPT can generate academic/professional writing easily.

2. Summarise papers. ChatGPT Is used as like a searching tool for the information in the papers.

3. Ask general questions like how is green steel produced, however it is not always trustworthy.

4. Generate code according to the description.

5.  Ask ChatGPT to spot any mistakes in my writing, and output the errors in a tabular format so I can improve my writing.
column7: Rewrite and generate ideas on how to answer questions
column8: Not quite, still require revision on their output

column6:
- Strategy - before starting each section, I would ask AI “how would I approach estimating a production capacity for a DRI plant in WA?” (example) And it would recommend a step by step approach which I would integrate with my own approach. Otherwise I would ask AI “Is this the right way to approach this:….” and it would refine my approach. 

- Writing Assistance - I would write my own paragraphs based on my research and calculations, and programmed my AI assistant to make the paragraphs “clear and concise” whilst keeping any statistical data. Sometime I would specify to frame the rewrite to emphasis a certain conclusion or critical thinking point. 

- Formatting - I would ask AI to reformat chunky paragraphs to a clearer format, which would normally consist of breaking the information into dot points that were easier to digest 

- Typical scaling values for economic values - I would ask what range the sensitivity analysis should be scaled to, and check this against research trends
column7: Mostly rewording paragraphs - especially after hours of work where you know what you want to say but your brain can't explain it professionally any more.
column8: Not entirely reliable - some of their suggested statistics weren't supported by sources I could find, so it felt more efficient to use it with the resources and understanding I already had and make it sound better, as oppose to go chasing after a source to support what it told me.

column6:
1. summarize long research paper for me.

2. put sentences together to sound professional and consice

3. generate reference APA 7

4. generate macro codes
column7: summarize research papers for me.
column8: it gives good general responses, but when asked to confirm sources or give specific answers it lags or contradicts itself, making it an unreliable information.

column6:
* Explain technical terms

* Help to brianstorm ideas

* Paraphrase or reduce my lengthy sentences

* Organize a daily routine/schedule for me as I felt too tired with three days work and 2 days uni 

* Consult with ChatGPT about anxiety raised approaching the deadline of assignments, it does provide some useful suggestions which helped me to finish my report on time
column7: The most useful tool for me not in the research or ideation but in consultation about anxiety ans stress. It does provide some useful suggestions which helped me to finish my report on time, such as set up a schedule to balance work & life with suitable workout plan and diet plan.
column8: It provides repeat solutions, need to do own research after that. Overall, it can provide some basic understanding with unfamiliar terms or project. Once I have developed some extend of background knowledge, the ChatGPT is not that useful any more.

column6:
* Early stage research about the topics to get a basic understanding so I could start more detailed research

* to turn dot-point/rough writing into more formal writing, although I usually had to re-write this again as i felt it lost some of the meaning

* Generating sections of code for specific actions in the macro

* helping to debug my vba code, by putting in the code and error messages

* when editing/crosschecking others’ report sections, I identified sentences to improve then asked ChatGPT to rewrite for clarity/formality etc
column7: While I didn’t use much pure ChatGPT written text, it was very useful in the intermediate stage of turning some ideas/dot points into the first draft of words which is often the most time consuming for me. Most of the time this still required me to go back through and fix some facts/data or critical thinking but this process was much faster than having to write fully from scratch.
column8: Coding outputs were very reliable, working most of the time. Writing output was always reliable in terms of grammar, good language etc but not always actually good at getting the ideas across. Technical information was not necessarily misleading, but most of the time it was just a bit of fluff rather than actually explaining anything, so was only helpful to get a very basic understanding of new topics.

column6:
Search engine: very useful to get an elementary understanding about new things, or search the specific information (but not reliable enough even for GPT 4o).

Translating between English and Chinese.

Reversing/Editing the draft.
column7:
Translating.

I will write my drafts with Chinese and English mixed together, with a ratio of about 8:2, and then use GPT to translate them into 100% English. After making simple revisions, I will use GPT for further polishing and editing.

I consider this is the most efficient help to me only because it's hard to ensure other main uses are reliable and able to make me satisfied, time will be wasted in checking the answers.
column8:
Not reliable, GenAi still have a long way to go.

Most of time, I do not ask a specific question to get a direct answer. Instead, I prefer to let GPT assist me in how to get more comprehensive and reliable information by myself. Afterall, for now, human brain have more to explore.

column6:
* Drafting Reports: Assisted in writing and refining sections of feasibility reports, including introductions, summaries, and conclusion paragraphs.

* Asked it to write an introduction for a green steel feasibility - then refined this through cowriting and adding specifics

* Data Interpretation: Helped analyse and interpret data related to green hydrogen and DRI production, applying insights from uploaded documents (RAG)

* For example: I had a bunch of uploaded documents then asked what a reasonable production capacity is and it gave a range which was a good starting point for our considerations

* Technical Writing and cowriting: Provided assistance in technical writing, ensuring clarity and fluency in complex engineering topics. Asked it to write a series of dot points into a paragraph and also asked it to rewrite paragraphs to make them more concise and shorter

* Methodology Clarification: Clarified methodologies for cost estimation, such as the Lang factor method, and provided advice on the application of these methods, specifically the uncertainty in different methodologies

* Document Summarisation: Summarised and synthesised key points from technical papers, reports, and other documents related to the project. For example, uploaded sections of text from a journal article and asked it to summarise/what the key points were.

* Ideation: Asked it what factors I need to consider in financial, environment and social feasibility and then used these points to direct research and also structure the write up.

* I also used ChatGPT to provide me these above dot points: I asked it in what ways I’ve used it over the last four weeks.
column7: Ideation - i wanted to make sure i had considered many aspects of social and environmental feasibility so after drafting the main points I wanted to write about I asked it what factors should be considered for environmental and social feasibility of the project. It gave me HEAPS, and many I didn't think of. It also gave them to me as a series of headings, with subheadings and dot points so i used this structure to order my discussion, and just wove in my own research to the overall outline it had given me, keeping ones that were relevant and disregarding points i didn't think were needed.
column8: It varied, depending on what you ask it. To ask it specifics on technical data was not a reliable source and often it did get things just completely wrong. But again for ideation/getting a general understanding of concepts it gave a reasonable output that then directed my research. Also it often gave me spelling mistakes, incoherent grammar, incorrect citations and a few times it completely glitched and gave me an answer to a question i didn't ask.

column6:
Ask following question, and use answer to search on google scholar

* What are the animals and plants around Port Hedland, are there any endangered species, are there any large mammals, and are there a large number of birds?

* Detailed description of Port Hedland and its surrounding environment.

* How many bird species are there in the protected area near Port Hedland?

* What are the wind power companies in Australia and the projects they operate?

* All possible technologies of DRI, please classify them as carbon dioxide emissions and non carbon dioxide emissions.

* If DRI can be obtained through direct electrolysis and the project can be implemented, what is the electricity cost range?
column7: The information searched is comprehensive, although not deep enough
column8: Extremely poor reliability, requiring self verification

column6: When I determine the task I am responsible for, I will first read the guidance on handbook and ask chat gpt if I am not clear. Also, when I'm out of ideas, I ask chat gpt to give me some ideas, and then go online and look for information on my own.
column7: When helping me come up with ideas and asking for information that I don't quite understand
column8: The calculation part is not very accurate, but the concept explanation is more accurate.

column6:
* Predominantly used for coding of VB in excel - ask chatGPT to write code based on plainlanguage instructions and iterating to build up code bit-by-bit

* Minor used in confirming facts or trying to find references for certain facts

* Asked it to design a title page that I ended up using the recommended colour scheme for

* Asked it to identifty spelling and grammar issues in final text but only picked up on <50%

* Got it to write an executive summary based on written report but did not use any of it as it was not what I wanted
column7: Was very useful for coding as it allowed me to quickly convert instructions into code for a language I did not know how to write, with easy troubleshooting and back-and-forth iteration. ChatGPT couldn't always provide working code, as a couple times I had to read the code to find errors in chatGPT's code that it could not identify.
column8: From my rather limited experience it can be varied - it can give reliable outputs but can also fill in the gaps with too much superfluous filler that is not appropriate for reportwriting

column6:
* Research - starting point for what topics to research, and broad summaries of topics to guide my more detailed research

* Intial drafting of sections - providing my research in dot points and using chat GPT to provide an initial draft

* Providing summaries of reports, websites and source materials
column7: It was quite useful, particularly the ability summarise large reports and provide the key details, which can then be used to read the most important sections
column8: It was okay at general information and overviews, however the more specific information was often lacking in detail or sometimes in correct.

column6:
1. Use GenAI to perform brainstorming to gather ideas for the outline of the strcuture of the report

2. Use GenAI to generate a general structure of the section I am writing

3. Use GenAI to make paragraphs more consistent and concise

4. Use GenAI to summarize the information and integrate them into my original paragraphs.
column7: The GPT was most useful for me to extract and summarize key information from the resource I found online, it saves me time on thinking how to express these information in a more clear and concise way.
column8: It is OK, sometimes the wording is not perfect and it may misunderstand the key points in the report when I asked it to summarize the content.

column6:
I mainly used it to co-write some sections through specific prompts and iteration. I find ChatGPT can be unwantedly creative when it comes to writing about technical parameters, so any assistance I received from ChatGPT was thoroughly vetted and commonly discarded.

I did use ChatGPTs RAG functionality to help filter through large documents. Any results supplied were also vetted to ensure accuracy.
column7: To help convert a brain-dump of ideas into coherent writing.
column8: Not hugely reliable to be honest. I found myself using it more for editing than anything else in the end.

column6:
* Paraphrasing: changing the wording of a paragraph

* Making paragraphs shorter or longer

* Researching

* Explanation of basic concepts(used to revise topics)

* Turning ideas(dot points) into a professional sounding paragraph 

* Writing code for excel macro
column7: Turning ideas(dot points) into a professional sounding paragraph
column8: medium reliability
